questions.text: The fibres from the contralateral nasal hemiretina project to the following layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Layers 1, 4 & 6 The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN, also called the lateral geniculate body or lateral geniculate complex) is a relay centre in the thalamus for the visual pathway. It receives a major sensory input from the retina. The LGN is the main central connection for the optic nerve to the occipital lobe, particularly the primary visual cortex. In humans, each LGN has six layers of neurons (grey matter) alternating with optic fibres (white matter). The LGN is a small, ovoid, ventral projection at the termination of the optic tract on each side of the brain.

Highyeild:

Six laminae of ‘grey matter’ and intervening white strata are composed of axons and dendrites. The grey laminae are like six irregularly stacked cones, ranging from one ventrally at the hilum to six dorsally. The two inner layers consist of loosely arranged large cells(magnocellular while the four outer layers consist of small and medium-sized cells(parvocellular).

Extraedge:

Position of Visual Fibres: Macular fibres coming in the optic tract occupy two thirds of LGB Upper retinal fibres occupy the medial half of the anterior one-third of LGB Lower Retinal fibres occupy the lateral half of the anterior one-third of the LGB

questions.text: The most common condition of inherited blindness to the mitochondrial chromosomal anomaly is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leber's Hereditary optic neuropathy Leber hereditary optic neuropathy Mitochondrial DNA inheritance due to point mutation at 11778 is materially transmitted; hence Males are affected more. Clinical features- Unilateral, sudden painless LOV, fellow eye involved after weeks to years results in bilateral visual loss Hyperemic disc with obscuration of disc margins and absence of leakage of dye on FFA Peripapillary telangiectatic microangiopathy Pseudo edema / pseudo papillitis Primary optic atrophy Central or centrocecal scotoma Normal pupillary reactions

Highyeild:

On OCT In affected carriers - the thickening of temporal retinal fibres seen In patients, thickening of the superior and infringes are seen in the acute phase When OA supervenes - pathognomonic sign - nerve fibre layer dropout of small fibres of papillomacular bundle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Retinopathy of prematurity:- Option: C. Retinitis Pigmentosa Option: D. Retinal Detachment

Extraedge:

There is no treatment available for this disease till now.

questions.text: A patient presents with Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary response. The site of involvement is most likely to be which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic tract Abnormalities of pupillary reactions Amaurotic light reflex . It refers to the absence of direct light reflex on the affected side (say, right eye) and the absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side (i.e., left eye). This indicates lesions of the optic nerve or retina on the affected side (i.e., right eye), leading to complete blindness. In diffuse illumination, both pupils are of equal size.

Highyeild:

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil. It indicates a lesion of the optic tract. In this condition, a light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half the opposite side.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side (say right eye) and presence of both direct and consensual Q light reflex on the normal side (i.e., left eye) indicates efferent pathway defect (sphincter paralysis). Near reflex is also absent on the affected side. Its causes include the effect of parasympatholytic drugs. (e.g., atropine, homatropine), internal ophthalmoplegia, and third nerve paralysis. Option: B. is the paradoxical response of a pupil to light in the presence of a relative afferent pathway defect (RAPD). Causes of Marcus Gunn's pupil include incomplete optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. It is tested by swinging flashlight test. Option: D. Here, both pupils are slightly small in size, and reaction to near reflex is a present, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e., there is light near dissociation (to remember, the acronym ARP may stand for 'accommodation reflex present') . Both pupils are involved and dilate poorly with mydriatics. It is caused by a lesion (usually neurosyphilis) in the region of the tectum.

Extraedge:

Adie's tonic pupil In this condition, reaction to light is absent, and the near reflex is slow and tonic . The affected pupil is larger (anisocoria ). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. It is usually unilateral , associated with an absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women. Adie's pupil constricts with weak pilocarpine (0.125%) drops, while the normal pupil does not because the denervated iris sphincter is super sensitive to topical parasympathomimetics.

questions.text: Relative colour and luminosity of photoreceptive input under changing light conditions are regulated and maintained by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amacrine cells Amacrine cells of the vertebrate retina are interneurons that interact at the second synaptic level of the vertically direct pathways of the photoreceptor-bipolar-ganglion cell chain . They are synaptically active in the inner plexiform layer (IPL) and serve to integrate, modulate, and interpose a temporal domain to the visual message presented to the ganglion cell.

Highyeild:

Amacrine cells are so named because they are nerve cells thought to lack an axon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Option: C. A drawing of a section through the human eye with a schematic enlargement of the retina.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented with sudden, severe bilateral vision loss, more so on the right side, with no light perception. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflex, fundus and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could touch the tips of her finger with her right eye closed but not with her left eye closed. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Functional visual loss NOVL is a decrease in visual acuity and/or visual field not caused by any organic lesion. NOVL cannot be explained by organic pathology after a complete neuro-ophthalmic examination. The decrease in visual acuity may involve one or both eyes and vary from mild blurriness to complete blindness.

Highyeild:

The visual field defects may affect one or both eyes. They may include constricted or tunnel visual fields, and hemianopias, among other complaints or visual findings.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Optic neuritis Option: B. CMV retinitis Option: C. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

Extraedge:

NOVL is often but not always associated with a concurrent diagnosis of depression and anxiety . The diagnosis of NOVL is frequently confirmed at the neuro-ophthalmologist's office after a referral from a general ophthalmologist.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a persistent headache for the past few months. On evaluation, her vision on Snellen's chart was 6/6 in both eyes. The fundus also appears to be normal. Visual field charting shows bitemporal visual field defects. The site of the lesion is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic chiasma Optic chiasma is a flattened structure 12 mm horizontally & 8mm anteroposteriorly ,4mm thick, ensheathed by pia mater and surrounded by CSF. It lies over diaphragma sellae, so visual field defects are seen in patients with pituitary tumours having suprasellar extension. Posteriorly, chiasma is continuous with the optic tracts & forms the anterior wall of the third ventricle.

Highyeild:

Optic chiasma lesions Central - bitemporal hemianopia Pituitary adenoma - bitemporal superior quadrantanopia Craniopharyngioma - bitemporal inferior quadrantanopia Lateral - binasal hemianopia Proximal optic nerve injury causes junctional scotoma Bitemporal hemianopsia (or bitemporal hemianopia) describes the ocular defect that leads to impaired peripheral vision in the outer temporal halves of the visual field of each eye. This condition commonly results from a tumor or lesion impinging on the optic chiasm, the decussation point of the optic nerve conveying visual information from the nasal retina in each eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Prelaminar optic nerve: Option: B. Optic nerve juxta lamina cribrosa Option: D. Optic tract

Extraedge:

The most common i ntrinsic lesion is the pituitary adenoma which may promote compression of the optic chiasma causing visual disturbances.

questions.text: What is the most likely site of lesion for the visual field defect?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Proximal optic nerve Signs of optic neuritis may include the following: Decreased pupillary light reaction in the affected eye: A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil commonly is found. In bilateral cases, the RAPD may not be apparent. Varying degrees of vision reduction: Ranging from a mild decrease in visual acuity to complete vision loss, which is often monocular but can be binocular Abnormal contrast sensitivity and color vision : In almost all patients with adult optic neuritis who have decreased visual acuity.

Highyeild:

Field defects : May include altitudinal, arcuate, nasal step, central scotoma, cecocentral scotoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Left Distal Optic Nerve Option: C. Left Macular Retinal Fibres Option: D. Right Temporal Lobe

Extraedge:

Initially, the optic nerve head may appear normal , with disc pallor months later. Papillitis (swollen disc) may be seen in one-third of patients with optic neuritis

questions.text: This patient, who is a known case of multiple sclerosis, developed diplopia 2 weeks ago, which was worse on looking to the right. Convergence is normal. Where is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left MLF Contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation , which then sends efferents to the ipsilateral CN VI nucleus at the level of the facial colliculus in the dorsal pons. Subsequently, the CN VI nucleus projects to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle (abducts the eye) and contralateral medial rectus subnucleus of CN III (adducts the eye) via the MLF. Unilateral MLF lesions can occur with lacunar stroke in the pontine artery distribution, although bilateral lesions are classically seen in multiple sclerosis.

Highyeild:

Lesions to the left dorsal pons can disrupt the left MLF, resulting in impaired adduction of the ipsilateral (left) eye during the right conjugate horizontal gaze. Patients also develop diplopia and horizontal nystagmus of the abducting (right) eye. Convergence and the pupillary light reflex are generally preserved

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. is incorrect because MLF lesions cause contralateral gaze palsy e Right MLF lesion causes Left gaze palsy, not right gaze palsy. Option: B. is incorrect because convergence remains normal Option: D. is incorrect because PPRF lesions cause ipsilateral gaze palsy i.e Left PPRF lesion causes Left gaze palsy, but the gaze palsy in the question is right gaze palsy.

Extraedge:

This patient has internuclear ophthalmoplegia, a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze resulting from damage to the heavily-myelinated fibers of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The MLF is a paired neural tract that mediates communication between CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei , allowing for coordinated horizontal eye movements.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man undergoes modified radical neck dissection for an oropharyngeal tumour. During the procedure, he requires multiple blood transfusions. Four hours after the surgery, examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the left eye. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic Nerve The patient presents with a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) . Given his need for multiple blood transfusions during surgery, the patient presumably had an episode of intraoperative blood loss . This blood loss could have resulted in hypotension and subsequent ischemic damage to a CNS structure involved in the pupillary response.

Highyeild:

A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) typically occurs because of unilateral damage to the retina and/or optic nerve (CN II). In this patient, damage to the optic nerve (CN II) due to ischemic optic neuropathy has resulted in RAPD.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Damage to the superior cervical ganglion and its sympathetic nerve fibres is a potential complication of radical deep neck dissection. However, patients in such cases would present with ipsilateral miosis and other symptoms of Horner syndrome (e.g. ptosis, anhidrosis). Option: C . Damage to the parasympathetic Edinger-Westphal nucleus , which contains the efferent pupillary response pathway, leads to absent pupillary reflex (direct and indirect) in the ipsilateral eye. In contrast, the pupillary reflex (direct and indirect) in the contralateral eye remains intact. Option: D . Damage to the lateral geniculate body leads to homonymous hemianopia of the contralateral visual field. The pupillary response pathway does not pass through the lateral geniculate body, so pupillary reactions to light would not be affected.

Extraedge:

Complete damage to CN II would also result in loss of vision on the affected side.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, metastatic lung cancer is diagnosed. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right dorsal optic radiation This patient's visual field defects indicate a lesion in the parietal lobe . The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field, i.e., from the right superior quadrant of both retinas. Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia ("pie on the floor") , as seen here. Option: C . The superior bundle of left optic radiations (left dorsal optic radiation) is located in the left parietal lobe and relays information from the right inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left superior bundle of optic radiations results in right lower homonymous quadrantanopsia , which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.ss Option: D .The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopsia ("pie in the sky"), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient. The inferior bundle of left optic radiations (left Meyer loop) is located in the left temporal lobe . It transmits visual information from the right superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left Meyer loop would result in right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia ("pie in the sky") , which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and nausea for 2 weeks. The headaches are worse on awakening, and she describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During this period, she has noticed a brief visual loss in both eyes lasting several seconds, especially when she suddenly stands up or bends over. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); her BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes with mild peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed; the opening pressure is 310 mm H2O. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 4/mm3 (75% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acetazolamide Therapy The presence of headaches, nausea, and transient vision loss in an obese woman with an unremarkable MRI and a raised opening pressure on the lumbar puncture indicates idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Acetazolamide is the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).

Highyeild:

Patients with newly-diagnosed IIH should stop taking any agents potentially causing symptoms (e.g., vitamin A analogs, tetracyclines), adopt a low sodium weight loss diet (if overweight), and begin acetazolamide.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Serial lumbar puncture is typically used in IIH patients to decrease intracranial pressure before surgery or in pregnant patients who decline pharmacotherapy. Lumbar puncture only temporarily treats IIH because CSF regenerates in ∼ 6 hours. Consequently, it is rarely indicated other than as a temporary measure in patients with IIH who are awaiting a more definitive therapy. Option: C . Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone ) are indicated as a supplement to first-line therapy in patients with IIH or in patients who present with moderate or progressive visual field loss. This patient has only mild visual field loss , so she should be started on first-line therapy before considering corticosteroids. Option: D. Optic nerve sheath fenestration is a first-line surgical treatment option for patients with IIH who have not responded to maximal medical management or in patients presenting with rapid, severe vision loss. This patient has only mild visual symptoms, so conservative management should be attempted before surgery can be considered.

Extraedge:

Although the mechanism is not clear, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) are believed to reduce the rate of CSF production, thereby decreasing intracranial hypertension.
